output.final_deliverable:
I searched the government, news, and research-institution sources included in the merged results and report what the available search evidence shows (I have included direct URLs). Where a precise population number/date was not captured in the search results I was given, I state that explicitly rather than guessing.

1) Government (U.S. Census Bureau QuickFacts)
- Population figure: Not available in the merged search snippets I was given. The QuickFacts page for San Francisco city / San Francisco County is the authoritative government source for population estimates; however the exact population value and reference date were not captured in the search results text available to me. I cannot state the Census Bureau figure without visiting that QuickFacts page.
- Date of the data: Not captured in the search snippets I received (QuickFacts pages normally show the population estimate reference date, e.g., July 1 of a given year). 
- Direct citation URL: https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/sanfranciscocitycalifornia/BZA110222

(If you want the exact Census Bureau number and date I should open that QuickFacts page and extract the value.)

2) News outlet (San Francisco Chronicle)
- Population figure: 837,165
- Date of the data: "this summer" (the Chronicle article reports this as the city population for summer 2024 / mid-2024). The article states the city "lost a net 1,086 people between July 2023 and July 2024," and gives 837,165 for the most-recent summer estimate reported in the piece.
- Direct citation URL: https://www.sfchronicle.com/sf/article/sf-population-loss-19993542.php

(Other Chronicle pieces in the merged results cite different figures for earlier reference dates: e.g., ~808,988 for July 2023 and ~834,000 for 2022 per the California Dept. of Finance — see links below.)
- Example earlier Chronicle cites: "808,988 residents as of July 2023" — https://www.sfchronicle.com/sf/article/s-f-population-exodus-over-18972239.php
- Example Chronicle citation of CA Dept. of Finance for 2022 (~834,000) — https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/census-population-18091853.php

3) Research institution (Brookings Institution)
- Population figure: Not provided in the merged search snippets I was given as an absolute number. The Brookings piece in the merged results reports percentage changes and notes San Francisco’s recent percent changes (for example, a 1% increase in 2023-24 relative to the prior period) but the merged snippet does not include an absolute population count.
- Date of the data: The Brookings analysis refers to the Census Bureau population-estimates period (e.g., 2023-24) in its discussion, but an absolute reference population was not captured in the search snippet I was given.
- Direct citation URL: https://www.brookings.edu/articles/recent-immigration-brought-a-population-rebound-to-americas-major-metro-areas-new-census-data-show/

Comparison, discrepancies, and likely-accurate figure
- Discrepancies visible in the merged search results come mainly from different reference dates and revisions: the Chronicle’s articles cite ~834,000 for 2022 (citing California Dept. of Finance), ~808,988 for July 2023 (citing Census data in that piece), and ~837,165 for summer 2024 (newer Chronicle piece). Brookings reports percent changes (e.g., a ~1% increase in 2023-24) but the merged snippet did not include an absolute population value. The Census QuickFacts page (the authoritative government source) is available in the search results but the exact population number and its reference date were not captured in the search snippet available to me.
- Why these discrepancies occur: different sources cite different reference dates (calendar-year vs. mid-year estimates), different datasets (California Department of Finance vs. U.S. Census Population Estimates Program), and some news pieces report the Census Bureau’s revised estimates while others report state figures or earlier estimates. Revisions and differing methodologies (state DOF vs. federal Census estimates) commonly cause small differences.
- Which figure is most likely accurate: the U.S. Census Bureau population estimates (as published on Census.gov/QuickFacts or the Census Population Estimates Program) are generally the most authoritative single-source nationwide estimates; state departments of finance (e.g., California Department of Finance) are also authoritative but may use different methods or revision timing. Because I could not extract the Census QuickFacts population number/date from the merged search results text I was given, I cannot state the exact Census figure here — but I would consider the Census Bureau’s most-recent estimate (QuickFacts or the Population Estimates Program) the best single figure to use if you need one authoritative number.

If you’d like, I can now open the Census QuickFacts page and the Brookings article to extract the exact Census population estimate (number and reference date) and the absolute population number Brookings may cite from its downloadable table. If you want that, say "Yes — fetch the Census and Brookings pages" and I’ll retrieve the precise figures and return an updated answer with all three numbers, dates, and direct citations.
output.action_summary: I found and linked the authoritative sources in the merged search results. From the SF Chronicle (news) the merged snippets show 837,165 for summer 2024 (article: https://www.sfchronicle.com/sf/article/sf-population-loss-19993542.php) and earlier Chronicle pieces show ~808,988 for July 2023 and ~834,000 for 2022. The U.S. Census Bureau QuickFacts page (government) is the authoritative source (https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/sanfranciscocitycalifornia/BZA110222) but the exact population value/date was not captured in the search snippets I was given, so I did not guess it. The Brookings research piece (https://www.brookings.edu/articles/recent-immigration-brought-a-population-rebound-to-americas-major-metro-areas-new-census-data-show/) reports percent changes (e.g., +1% in 2023-24) but the merged snippet did not include an absolute population count. Because the Census Bureau estimates are usually the most authoritative, the Census QuickFacts (most-recent estimate) is the figure I would rely on — I can fetch and report that exact number and date if you want me to open the Census and Brookings pages now.

merged_results.title: Retrieve population reported by a major news outlet

result.query: San Francisco population "population" site:sfchronicle.com OR site:nytimes.com OR site:latimes.com OR site:washingtonpost.com "San Francisco population" 2022 2023 2024
result.intent: Find a reputable news outlet's recent report citing a San Francisco population figure; capture the population number, the date of the data cited, and a direct citation URL.

results.title: S.F.’s population drops again as city struggles to retain residents
results.description: The new data confirms that San Francisco’s population is shrinking once again, having also seen a population decline from 2023 to 2024. Like the rest of California, the city’s population plunged after the start of the pandemic.

results.title: How many people live in San Francisco — and how many have left? We have a best guess
results.description: By Christian Leonard, Data ReporterUpdated May 25, 2023 11:31 a.m. A little more than 834,000 people lived in San Francisco in 2022, according to the California Department of Finance. But the U.S.

results.title: The S.F. region still leads the nation in population loss this decade
results.description: The San Francisco-Oakland-Fremont metropolitan area’s population grew 0.8% between July 2023 and July 2024, a gain of about 39,000 residents to a total of 4.64 million residents.

results.title: S.F.’s population drops once again in an ominous sign for the city’s recovery
results.description: The city lost a net 1,086 people between July 2023 and July 2024, a drop of 0.13%. Its population was 837,165 this summer, and revised data shows that the city has continued to lose people in each year since 2020.

results.title: San Francisco population falls to lowest level in over a decade
results.description: San Francisco saw a drop of about 4,400 people, or 0.5% of its population, between July 2021 and July 2022, a smaller decline than the 3.7% population loss in the prior year.

results.title: Is the San Francisco exodus over? Here’s what population data shows
results.description: Data shows that San Francisco is drawing more people in than it is losing, though the city remains smaller by roughly 22,000 people than it was in mid-2020.

results.title: The San Francisco exodus is over — but data points to slow recovery
results.description: The city’s population increased to an estimated 808,988 residents as of July 2023, up 0.15% from the prior year’s revised 807,774, according to census data released late Wednesday.

results.title: These charts show the most detailed data on how California's population is changing by county
results.description: The data shows the population of San Franciscans under 30 decreased by 18% from April 2020 to June 2023, with the largest declines among zero-4 year olds (-15%) and those ages 25-34 (-20%).

results.title: Will S.F.’s population grow in the future? New study predicts city may follow a different trend than others
results.description: A new study finds that San Francisco is poised to see population growth by the year 2100, even as other cities lose population.

results.title: Data shows which groups are coming back after San Francisco exodus
results.description: The Chronicle analyzed detailed data from the Census Bureau released Thursday that estimates populations each year by age, sex, race and ethnicity. To determine the demographic groups most likely to have come back from their pandemic exodus, the Chronicle examined percent changes in population groups between 2020 and 2022 — the year the city’s population hit a low — and again between 2022 and 2024.

merged_results.title: Retrieve population reported by a research institution (e.g., PRB, Brookings, PPIC, World Population Review, academic sources)

result.query: San Francisco population site:prb.org OR site:brookings.edu OR site:ppic.org OR "World Population Review" "San Francisco" population 2022 2023 2024
result.intent: Find a research institution's population estimate for San Francisco (Population Reference Bureau, Brookings, PPIC, World Population Review, academic papers), including the figure, data date, and direct citation URL.

results.title: California's Population
results.description: California lost 322,000 people between July 2020 and July 2022. Most of this loss occurred during the first year of the pandemic and was driven by a sharp rise in residents moving to other states.

results.title: Census shows big city population improvements, countering predictions of the ‘urban doom loop’ | Brookings
results.description: In the most recent year’s census statistics (2022–2023), two thirds of these big cities showed demographic improvements—through greater population gains, fewer losses, or shifts from losses to gains—compared with 2020–2021.

results.title: D ATA S H E E T WORLD POPULATION 2023 *END OF 2022 WORLD POPULATION
results.description: D ATA S H E E T · WORLD POPULATION · *END OF 2022 · WORLD · POPULATION · 8.01 BILLION · GLOBAL TOTAL · FERTILITY RATE · 2.2 BIRTHS · INTERNALLY DISPLACED

results.title: Recent immigration brought a population rebound to America’s major metro areas, new census data show | Brookings
results.description: In fact, among 37 selected core ... noteworthy was the city of San Francisco, where the population declined by 6.8 % in 2020-21, but increased by 1% in 2023-24 (see downloadable Table D)....

results.title: Bay Area Tops in Population Growth Rates
results.description: To some extent, local authorities and builders have responded to this demand with new housing construction, much of it multi-unit housing in densely populated areas. Population growth has been especially strong in Santa Clara and Alameda Counties, but San Francisco and San Mateo Counties are also outpacing the more suburban parts of the Bay Area, such as Sonoma and Solano Counties.

results.title: World and U.S. Population Trends | Focus Areas | PRB
results.description: Changes in a population’s size, growth rate, and composition can have profound effects on society, the economy, and individual health and well-being. PRB tracks the key demographic trends underlying global population change and helps decision makers understand these trends and their implications.

results.title: New census data hints at an urban population revival, assisted by immigration | Brookings
results.description: In contrast, 18 of the 20 major metro areas with greatest population losses lost fewer people in 2022-23 than in 2021-22, led by Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, New Orleans, San Francisco, and Pittsburgh.

results.title: Big cities are showing signs of recovery after historic population losses, new census data shows | Brookings
results.description: This data is compiled by the Census Bureau’s population estimates program: evaluation estimates for the period 2010-2020 and vintage 2022 estimates for 2020-2021 and 2021-2022.

results.title: PRB's 2024 World Population Data Sheet
results.description: The 2024 World Population Data Sheet provides the latest population, health, and environment indicators for more than 200 countries and territories, each carefully researched by PRB’s expert team of demographers and analysts.

results.title: Data Sheets | PRB
results.description: PRB data sheets are ready references of demographic and health indicators by country and region including population projections and key data insights · Population Reference Bureau 1111 19th St. NW Suite 400 Washington, DC 20036
